title: 1554 Yugoslavia
text:
1554 Yugoslavia, provisional designation , is a stony Eunomian <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> from the middle region of the <a href="asteroid%20belt">asteroid belt</a>, approximately in diameter. It was discovered by Serbian astronomer <a href="Milorad%20Proti%C4%87">Milorad Protić</a> at <a href="Belgrade%20Astronomical%20Observatory">Belgrade Astronomical Observatory</a>, Serbia, on 6 September 1940. It was named for the former country of <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>.
Orbit and classification.
The asteroid is a member of the <a href="Eunomia%20family">Eunomia family</a>, a large group of mostly stony <a href="S-type%20asteroid">S-type asteroid</a>s and the most prominent family in the intermediate main-belt. It orbits the Sun in the <a href="Kirkwood%20gap">central</a> main-belt at a distance of 2.1–3.1 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 4 years and 3 months (1,548 days). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.20 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 12<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>. "Yugoslavia" was first identified as at <a href="Uccle%20Observatory">Uccle Observatory</a> in 1932. Its <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins 4 year prior to its official discovery observation, with a <a href="precovery">precovery</a> taken at <a href="Nice%20Observatory">Nice Observatory</a> in 1936.
Physical characteristics.
From 2007 to 2012, several photometric <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> observations of "Yugoslavia" established a well-defined <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a> of 3.89 hours with a brightness variation between 0.64 and 0.74 <a href="Magnitude%20%28astronomy%29">magnitude</a> ().
According to the surveys carried out by the Japanese <a href="Akari%20%28satellite%29">Akari</a> satellite and NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a> with its subsequent <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission, "Yugoslavia" measures between 14.73 and 21.39 kilometers in diameter, and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> between 0.070 and 0.269. The "Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link" assumes an albedo of 0.21 – derived from <a href="15%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BEunomia">15 Eunomia</a>, the family's largest member and namesake – and calculates a diameter of 15.94 kilometers with an <a href="absolute%20magnitude">absolute magnitude</a> of 11.3.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named after the former country of <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>. The official was published by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a> on 30 January 1964 ().
